headline: ATF Evaluating Whether NBC News ‘Ghost Guns’ Segment Broke the Law
author: Zachary Leeman
sentences: “ATF greatly values the public’s assistance in providing information about potential violations of the Federal firearms and explosives laws,” an ATF spokesman told The Reload, an outlet covering the gun industry.
The controversial part of the segment came when NBC News reporter Vaughn Hillyard bought a “ghost gun” kit outside of his home state and then gave it to others to build into a full firearm.
Enough controversy was kicked up that the ATF provided an official response on Thursday that did not confirm whether or not an investigation would occur based on the complaints.
Gun rights activists say the actions violate federal law, and argued that potentially guilty members of the press should be investigated just like any other individual.
Gun rights activists have argued that a transfer of a handgun kit across state lines would be subject to a background check from a gun dealer as a full firearm would.
It’s illegal for us and it’s illegal for them,” the legal counsel for Gun Owners of America, Andrew Austin, complained about the report in a statement to The Reload.

An NBC News segment highlighting the “ghost gun” market in the U.S. has earned a response from the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives.
The agency did add that all tips they have received will be “evaluated” and “referred to the responsible ATF Field Division” based on resources and availability.
The March 17 report covered so-called “ghost gun” kits that offer firearm parts which can be built into guns, which don’t have serial numbers.
“Ghost gun” kits have been a bit of a legal grey area as the ATF has promised they are working to end loopholes related to these kits.
In the segment, Hillyard also has his firearm put together by off-camera hands working for Pennsylvania Attorney General Josh Shapiro.
“That leaves some ambiguity until the rule is adopted,” firearms reporter and The Reload founder Stephen Gutowski tweeted.
“They aren’t permitted to make guns for third parties or transfer firearms to others without getting a background check.
Activists have been claiming the network may have broken the very laws they were trying to expose as too lenient.
If they are, transferring across state lines without a proper background check is a clear violation of the law.
The grey area is currently whether some of these kits are considered actual firearms.
